description: A classic bottom-dwelling fish, easily recognised by its mottled green or sandy brown back, a distinctive single barbel on its chin, and a prominent white lateral line. They are powerful fish, especially when they reach larger sizes.
habitatAndBehaviour: Cod prefer cooler, deeper water and are often found over rough, broken ground, reefs, and wrecks. They are voracious predators, feeding on a wide variety of food including worms, crabs, shellfish, and smaller fish.
conservationNote: North Sea and Atlantic cod stocks have been under significant pressure. Many anglers advocate for returning fish under 50-60cm to allow them to grow to breeding size.
identificationNote: Can be confused with Pollack or Coalfish, but the chin barbel is the key giveaway.

description: A prized sport fish renowned for its fighting qualities. It has a streamlined, silver body with a darker blue-grey back and a cream or white belly. Key identifying features include two distinct dorsal finsâ€”the first being spiny and sharp.
habitatAndBehaviour: Adaptable predators found in a range of coastal habitats, from shallow estuaries and surf beaches to deeper water over reefs and wrecks. They often feed aggressively in turbulent water.
conservationNote: A very slow-growing species. Strict regulations govern recreational bass fishing, including a closed season for retention (catch and release only), a higher minimum legal size, and strict bag limits (e.g., two fish per angler per day) during the open season. Anglers must check current legislation.

description: A powerful predator with a coppery-brown back, large eyes, and a distinctly underslung lower jaw. Its lateral line has a noticeable curve over the pectoral fin.
habitatAndBehaviour: Pollack are ambush predators that live in and around structures like deep-water rock marks, kelp forests, reefs, and wrecks. They hunt in mid-water, darting out from cover.
identificationNote: Anglers frequently confuse Pollack with Coalfish. A Pollack has a protruding lower jaw and a dark, kinked lateral line. A Coalfish has jaws of roughly equal length and a straight, pale lateral line.

description: Also known as Saithe, the Coalfish has a dark, greenish-black back and bright silvery flanks. Its definitive identifying feature is its pale, straight lateral line.
habitatAndBehaviour: Coalfish share a preference for rocky ground and wrecks with Pollack but are more prone to forming large shoals, especially when young.

description: A slender member of the cod family, recognised by its silvery body and a small but distinct dark blotch at the base of each pectoral fin.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found over a variety of seabeds, including mud, sand, and gravel. They are aggressive shoaling predators that move into shallower water to feed in winter.

description: A long, eel-like member of the cod family, primarily caught by boat anglers over deep-water wrecks and reefs. It has a single, long chin barbel.
habitatAndBehaviour: Lives in deep water, hiding in wrecks and rocky crevices. A powerful predator of fish and squid.

description: A member of the cod family distinguished by a black lateral line and a dark blotch above the pectoral fin, often called the 'thumbprint'.
habitatAndBehaviour: A bottom-dwelling fish found over sand, gravel, and shell, typically in deeper water than cod.

description: A small, deep-bodied member of the cod family with a copper-coloured body and a distinct chin barbel. Known for its willingness to take almost any bait.
habitatAndBehaviour: Forms dense shoals around structures like piers, breakwaters, and wrecks.

description: A smaller cousin of the Pouting, often found in the same habitats. It is more slender and generally lighter in colour.
habitatAndBehaviour: Shoals around underwater structures, often mixed in with Pouting.

description: An eel-like bottom dweller, easily identified by its three barbels: one on the chin and two on the snout. Often found in rockpools and under stones.
habitatAndBehaviour: Lives in rocky, weedy areas close to the shore. A nocturnal scavenger.

description: The Ballan is the largest and most common wrasse species in the UK. It is a deep-bodied, powerful fish with thick lips and strong, peg-like teeth designed for crushing the shells of its prey. Its colouration is famously variable, ranging from dark green and brown to mottled orange and red.
habitatAndBehaviour: All wrasse are intrinsically linked to rough ground. They inhabit rocky shorelines, kelp forests, and areas with heavy weed cover, where they hunt for crustaceans, molluscs, and worms.
conservationNote: A very slow-growing fish. Best practice is catch and release to protect local populations.

description: The Cuckoo Wrasse is one of the most strikingly beautiful fish in UK waters. The male is unmistakable, with a bright blue head and back and a vibrant orange or yellow body. The female is a more subdued rose-pink or orange.
habitatAndBehaviour: Inhabits rocky shorelines, kelp forests, and areas with heavy weed cover, where they hunt for crustaceans, molluscs, and worms.

description: A smaller species of wrasse, often with a dark spot behind the eye and another at the base of the tail. Males can be very colourful during breeding season.
habitatAndBehaviour: Common in shallow, weedy, rocky areas and rockpools.

description: A small, slender wrasse, typically golden or reddish-brown with a distinct black spot on the front of the dorsal fin and another on the tail base.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found in rocky areas and kelp beds, often slightly deeper than other small wrasse.

description: A beautifully streamlined pelagic predator with a blue-green back marked with distinctive wavy black bars. The flanks and belly are a bright, pearlescent silver.
habitatAndBehaviour: Mackerel migrate inshore in vast numbers during summer to feed on huge shoals of small baitfish, such as sandeels and sprats, around piers, breakwaters, and headlands.
conservationNote: The MCRS is 30cm in the North Sea area, and 20cm elsewhere, but it's good practice to adhere to 30cm everywhere. Only take what you need for bait or the table.

description: Often mistaken for mackerel, the Scad has a duller, greyish body and a very prominent, ridged lateral line made of bony scutes.
habitatAndBehaviour: A shoaling, pelagic fish often found mixed with mackerel, feeding on small fish and crustaceans.

description: An unmistakable species with an extremely long, slender, silver body and a pair of elongated jaws that form a beak filled with needle-sharp teeth. Its bones are a vibrant green colour.
habitatAndBehaviour: Garfish are pelagic, surface-dwelling fish that arrive in UK waters in the summer to feed on small fish. They are known for their acrobatic fights when hooked.

description: Grey Mullet are powerful, torpedo-shaped, silvery fish that are notoriously wary and difficult to tempt. This species has a characteristically thick upper lip.
habitatAndBehaviour: Mullet are shoaling fish commonly found in calm waters such as harbours, marinas, and estuaries. They are primarily vegetarians and detritivores, feeding on algae and small invertebrates.

description: Similar to other mullet species, but can be distinguished by its thin upper lip. A wary and challenging species to catch.
habitatAndBehaviour: Commonly found in calm waters such as harbours, marinas, and estuaries, often further upriver than other species.

description: A powerful, torpedo-shaped, silvery fish. This species has a thin upper lip and a distinct golden spot on its gill cover.
habitatAndBehaviour: Prefers fully saline water, common in harbours and surf beaches on southern coasts, feeding on algae and small invertebrates.

description: A deep-bodied, silvery-grey fish that turns almost black during spawning season. A popular sport fish known for strong fights.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found over rough ground and reefs, migrating inshore to spawn in spring.

description: A powerful bream species, identified by the golden band between its eyes. Known for its hard fighting nature and ability to crush shells.
habitatAndBehaviour: Prefers estuaries and shallow coastal waters, feeding on shellfish and crabs.

description: Gurnards have a tapering body and a large, bony-plated head. Their first three pectoral fin rays are modified into 'legs' used to probe the seabed. The Red Gurnard is a bright red or pinkish colour.
habitatAndBehaviour: Bottom-dwelling fish found over sand, gravel, and mud. They are predators that feed on crustaceans, worms, and small fish.

description: The smallest and most common gurnard species, typically greyish-brown in colour with small white spots. Its lateral line is made of thorny, bony scales.
habitatAndBehaviour: Bottom-dwelling fish found over sand, gravel, and mud. They are predators that feed on crustaceans, worms, and small fish.

description: The largest gurnard species, often red or orange. It is definitively identified by its huge pectoral fins, which have a vibrant, iridescent blue fringe.
habitatAndBehaviour: Bottom-dwelling fish found over sand, gravel, and mud. They are predators that feed on crustaceans, worms, and small fish.

description: The most reliable identifier is the presence of prominent, bright orange or red spots scattered across its brown upper side. The skin is smooth to the touch.
habitatAndBehaviour: Prefers clean sandy or gravelly seabeds in clear water, from the shoreline down to 100m.

description: The defining characteristic is the texture of the skin, which has rows of rough, bony tubercles. Their colour is typically a drab olive-brown or grey.
habitatAndBehaviour: Famously tolerant of low-salinity water, Flounder are abundant in estuaries and tidal rivers, as well as on muddy and sandy shorelines.

description: The Dab can be distinguished by its lateral line, which has a distinct, high curve over the pectoral fin. Its skin feels rough like fine sandpaper if stroked from tail to head.
habitatAndBehaviour: A common inhabitant of shallow, sandy bottoms, often found in large numbers.

description: Despite its name, not a true sole. A right-eyed flatfish with a small head and mouth, and smooth, slimy skin.
habitatAndBehaviour: Prefers deeper water over gravel or sandy seabeds.

description: A large, powerful, almost circular left-eyed flatfish. Its skin is scaleless but covered in bony tubercles. A prized catch for its size and eating quality.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found on sandy and gravelly seabeds, a powerful predator of small fish.

description: Similar in shape to Turbot but more oval, and its skin is smooth with no tubercles. Also a left-eyed flatfish.
habitatAndBehaviour: Lives on sandy and mixed seabeds, preying on small fish.

description: The Dover Sole has a distinctly different shape from the other common flatfish. It is more oval or tongue-shaped, with a rounded snout and a small, curved mouth located on the underside of its head.
habitatAndBehaviour: Lives on sandy or muddy seabeds, often partially burying itself during the day and becoming more active at night.

description: Also known as the Small-Spotted Catshark, this is one of the most common shark species in UK waters. It has a slender body, a blunt head, and famously rough skin covered in numerous small, dark brown or black spots.
habitatAndBehaviour: An abundant bottom-dweller, found over sandy, gravelly, and muddy seabeds. It is an opportunistic scavenger, using its powerful sense of smell to locate almost any food source.

description: Also known as the Nursehound, the Bull Huss is a larger, more powerfully built cousin of the LSD. It is distinguished by its spots, which are much larger and fewer in number.
habitatAndBehaviour: Unlike the LSD, the Bull Huss has a strong preference for rough, rocky ground, reefs, and wrecks, where it hunts for fish, squid, and large crustaceans.

description: The Smooth-hound is a sleek, powerful, shallow-water shark. Instead of sharp teeth, they have blunt, powerful crushing plates designed for breaking the shells of their prey.
habitatAndBehaviour: Smooth-hounds are typically found over sandy, shingle, and light broken ground, where they actively hunt for their primary food source: crustaceans, especially crabs and lobsters.
conservationNote: No official MCRS, but catch and release is strongly encouraged to protect stocks.

description: The most commonly encountered ray for UK shore anglers. It has a classic diamond or kite-shaped body and is covered in sharp spines or 'thorns' across its back and down its tail.
habitatAndBehaviour: Thornbacks are found over a wide variety of seabeds, including mud, sand, shingle, and gravel, and are common in estuaries and deep channels.
conservationNote: The MCRS is measured from wingtip to wingtip. Anglers should handle them with extreme care to avoid the sharp thorns and return them to the water as quickly as possible.

description: A large ray species found on clean, sandy ground. It is sandy brown in colour, covered in small dark spots that extend to the very edge of the wings.
habitatAndBehaviour: Prefers clean sand and gravel seabeds, where it hunts for sandeels and other small fish.

description: A medium-sized ray with noticeably small eyes. It has a greyish-brown colour with pale, wavy lines and light spots that do not extend to the wing edges.
habitatAndBehaviour: A nocturnal feeder found over sand and mud, often very close to shore.

description: A smaller ray species, light brown in colour with prominent dark spots that do not extend to the wing edges. The spots are often eye-catching and well-defined.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found on sandy and gravelly ground, often in shallower water than other rays.

description: A very distinctive ray with dark, wavy lines and patterns on its back, interspersed with white spots. A protected species for many years, now making a comeback.
habitatAndBehaviour: Found over sand and mud, particularly on the central south coast of England.
conservationNote: Endangered species. Must be returned if caught by law.

description: The Conger is a large, powerful marine eel with a long, cylindrical, scaleless body. It is typically slate-grey or blue-black on its back, fading to a lighter, off-white belly.
habitatAndBehaviour: Congers are nocturnal predators that inhabit holes and crevices in rough ground, wrecks, piers, and harbour walls. They emerge at night to hunt for fish, crabs, and cephalopods.
conservationNote: No MCRS. Best practice is to handle with extreme care and return large specimens.
